settings.paragraph_top:
In the foothills of the Alps in northern Italy, Stefano La Mastra is relentlessly etching his name into the annals of the region's extreme sporting history.

Born in 1982, Stefano has dedicated his adult life to an untiring pursuit of some of Europe's most gruelling and seemingly impossible challenges. The Lombardy native has hit Everesting feats from Madonna del Ghisallo to Stelvio, and in 2023 took on a cycling, running and mountaineering climb of the Piz Bernina, the highest mountain in the Eastern Alps.
settings.paragraph_right:
To reach these kinds of heights, most athlete journeys begin with years of rigid training schedules imposed since childhood. But Stefano's route into sport was a steady transformation driven by a passion for the outdoors:

"Day after day, without even realising it, I became an athlete as a consequence of my passion for exploration—practically the opposite of 99% of athletes. I tried to figure out how I could spend my life exploring, and becoming an athlete was the answer."

His evolution was accelerated by his inexhaustible desire to put in the hard work. Not content with the idea of simply winning races or smashing records, Stefano fell in love with the lifestyle.
settings.paragraph_two_columns_1:
"I discovered that I loved everything I had to do to try and become an athlete—the training, the commitment, the effort".

The extreme cyclist’s unwavering dedication to his craft is plain to see. Before quitting his job and dedicating himself full time to his sport, Stefano juggled work and riding commitments with the kind of inexhaustible discipline that only the most fervent amongst us can comprehend. After grinding away during the working week, it was pretty routine to see him spend 14 hours in the saddle on a Saturday. 

These choices and sacrifices are the cornerstones of his training philosophy and mirror his dedication to living authentically and true to himself. While we’re so often forced to choose between passion and pragmatism, Stefano stands firmly on the side of feeling.
settings.paragraph_two_columns_2:
"More and more people, sometimes out of necessity—or out of choice—live a life that is not their own; a life that doesn't really make them happy. We should have the courage to live according to our patterns, our priorities, no matter what they are." 

His happiness emanates from committing to his ideas, making sacrifices, and embracing rules. “I like to respect rules”, he explains, “and, where possible, break them too." His ability to find beauty in the rules and the discipline demanded by sport have helped him through some long, painful rides and arduous climbs.

During the Madonna del Ghisallo Everesting challenge, Stefano called upon his inner discipline and courage to churn out eleven crushing climbs, 234 kilometres and a staggering 9077 metres elevation gain. Pedal after pedal, he was able to harness his discipline and turn his fatigue into satisfaction. 

Stefano’s journey from keen explorer to extreme athlete is a testament to his unwavering pursuit of his passion. With each weekend out riding, and every evening spent training, he writes the script for us all to embrace the rules that shape our experiences and live life on our own terms.
settings.banner_top: "More and more people, sometimes out of necessity—or out of choice—live a life that is not their own; a life that doesn't really make them happy. We should have the courage to live according to our patterns, our priorities, no matter what they are."
